document.ModsDocTitle: A new species group in the genus Dichaetophora, with descriptions of six new species from the Oriental region (Diptera, Drosophilidae)
document.docAuthor: Yang, Jin-Hua, Toda, Masanori J., Suwito, Awit, Hashim, Rosli & Gao, Jian-Jun
document.docTitle: Dichaetophora flatosternata Yang & Gao, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species group in the genus Dichaetophora, with descriptions of six new species from the Oriental region (Diptera, Drosophilidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species group in the genus Dichaetophora, with descriptions of six new species from the Oriental region (Diptera, Drosophilidae)

subSubSection.paragraph: Dichaetophora flatosternata Yang & Gao sp. n. Figs 3 H-J , 4 K-O , 7
Holotype. ♂ (#04172), CHINA: Mengyuan Substation, Mengla Station, Xishuangbanna National Nature Reserve, Guanlei, Mengla, Xishuangbanna, Yunnan, 14-15.xi.2012, JJ Gao (KIZ).
Paratypes: same data as holotype (5♂, 2♀: #04171, #04173-4178, KIZ, SEHU).

caption.paragraph: Figure 7. Dichaetophora flatosternata sp. n. (A−I #04172 J−L paratype #04177). A, B Periphallic organs (posterior and posterolateral view, respectively) C surstyli and cerci D, E tenth sternite (ventral and anterior view, respectively) F−H phallic organs (ventral, ventrolateral and lateral view, respectively) I paramedian setae J, K oviscapt (lateral and ventral view, respectively) L spermatheca (lateral view). Scale bars: 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Wing largely clouded, except for central pale patch around dm-cu vein and periphery (Fig. 3J); dorsolateral tentorial apodemes slightly divergent in basal half (Fig. 4M); tenth sternite nearly flat (Fig. 7E); oviscapt valve half as broad as long (Fig. 7J).
Wings (Fig. 3J): Veins pale brown to dark brown, but pale within central pale patch. Halter pale gray; stem darker.

Legs (Fig. 3H) pale grayish yellow; foreleg tibia and tarsus, mid-leg femur and distal portion of hindleg femur darker. Hindleg tibia lacking apical seta. Mid-leg first tarsomere longer than total length of four succeeding tarsomeres; hindleg first tarsomere as long as total length of four succeeding tarsomeres.
Referring to the flat male tenth sternite.
